summary: The John Kennedy Assassination is referenced in several NSA documents. Following the assassination on November 22, 1963, instructions were sent to Cuban diplomatic missions to refrain from making any statements. The South Korean Foreign Minister was asked to attend Kennedy's funeral in Washington. An NSA SIGINT Command Center report noted the termination of an alert in Oriente province, Cuba, after the assassination. Prince Sihanouk of Cambodia condemned the U.S. in a speech following Kennedy's death, also discussing Cambodian relations with France and Vietnam. These documents highlight the immediate international reactions and operational adjustments following the assassination.
significance: The assassination of John Kennedy triggered immediate international reactions and operational changes, as evidenced by the responses from Cuba, South Korea, and Cambodia, as well as internal adjustments within the NSA. These documents provide a glimpse into the global impact and the immediate aftermath of this significant historical event.
